Sometimes you wonder whether to go to see a film adaptation of a book for fear that they'll have ruined it, particularly when the book in question is a Hugo and Nebula award winner.

Sometimes, however, such fears can be confounded and they do a stonkingly good adaptation, relatively minor and fairly innocuous liberties with fine details of the story, sensitive cutting and abridging to accommodate the limitations of the medium, a distinct lack of a significant attempt to shy away from some of the darker aspects of the source and plenty of direct quotables for those who actually know the book and have a good memory. (Perhaps this was one occasion when having the original author as one of the executive producers has been a really good thing.)

If you haven't already guessed which book I'm referring to from the title of this post already I'll spell it out as clearly as possible. If you read and liked Ender's Game by Orson Scott Card, you might want to give the film a try, I really don't think you'll be disappointed.

As those who attended this year's CON may or may not have noticed, given I lugged it all the way down, rode it exactly once and then lugged it all the way back again, I've started cycling regularly again. It's been the only thing that has, more or less, made work, which is programming yet again, something I still seem to hate with a passion, borderline bearable. Well, that and, you see, I have this mad inclination to try riding l'etape next year so I've really got to get some proper training in this year.

Just by way of background I should note that although my house is still north of Manchester, my job is near Stroud in Gloucestershire, not the most ideal of situations as it involves a weekly commute, rented accomodation and other assorted double bills. The company itself might be full of lovely people and have a great atmosphere, there was even Champagne and a break to watch the Olympic torch go by, but I'm afraid I still wait with breathless anticipation for the end of my one year contract at the beginning of August, it's probably wrong to be looking forward to being unemployed again, but hey, such is my life.

Work stresses aside, the consolation is that that bit of the Cotswolds does have the benefit of being lumpy from a cycling point of view; the 4 mile ride in to work has about 100m of climbing to it and the ride home, usually rather indirectly 21 miles via Gloucester, has some further climbing and then the consolation of a couple of miles of pure downhill fun, that'd be 40mph of fun according to my recently acquired cycling computer. So all in all, at the moment I've able to put in about 100 miles during the working week and then get in a weekend run up the Cat and Fiddle near my parents back North for another 20 or 30 miles depending upon route. The Cat and Fiddle (400m or so of ascent) is kind of useful as, although it's not awfully steep, it's quite a long climb so I believe it would normally be classified as a Cat. 1 climb for races. We'll gloss over the fact that I probably need to be able to do my C. & F. loop five times consecutively to realistically be vaguely l'etape ready so there's obviously still a lot of work to do.

There are also one or two 'interesting' hills down near work, I discovered one by accident on a longer evening run home from work, about 30 indirect miles, this time via Cirencester. The hill in question from Brockworth up to Birdlip has, on the OS map, a couple of single arrow sections, that's a gradient of between 1:7 and 1:5 for those not in the know. What the OS map neglected to inform me was that, at least from my percieved level of trauma going up it, the rest of the hill is probably only just under 1:7 too, and over a mile of that is just plain unpleasant for climbing lardy-pusses like me.

So where's this wandering and rambling tale of my cycling exploits going. Well, the aforementioned cycling computer was the new tool for me to better judge whether I'd made a foolish decision. The foolish decision in question was signing up for an organised bike ride on bank holiday Monday. The ride I'd signed up for required me to be able to manage an average of 18mph for 52 miles and, at least historically, that's not the speed at which I used to get anywhere on my old mountain bike. However, it turned out that, now that I actually had measurements, I was in for a reasonably pleasant surprise, my speed on the flatter sections of the home run each night through Gloucester were hovering nicely around the required speed and although my average cadence wasn't quite where I'd like it to be it was closer to the desirable range than I had expected, so I was actually reasonably reassured that I hadn't been completely mad.

So, at ridiculous o'clock on Monday morning I was setting out for the center of Manchester to ride 52 miles on closed roads, yep, the organisers http://www.greatcycle.org had managed to arrange closed roads for the ride that pretty much blocked any easy north south passage through the city for vehicles. Not that I cared, 'cause I'd eventually be on them on my bike. Start was at about 8am and I finished in just over 2hrs 43 minutes with pretty consistent lap times. So in summary, for my first ever sportive ride, I had an absolute blast and just in case you hadn't guessed yet, that rider in the icon of this GIP, that's me.

Oh dear... , oh dear... , oh dear, oh dear, oh dear, Tron Legacy. 

I had always suspected from first seeing trailers that this was probably not a wise film to see if you'd loved the original and I really wasn't going with terribly high expectations, but honestly, did the makers actually even watch the original before making this horror. I can't believe I actually shelled out cash and stayed up till past midnight last night (yes, I might be a bit of an obsessive cinema goer) to see it.

I suppose accusing the makers of not seeing the original is perhaps a little unkind as there are a couple of direct quote lifts in there, perhaps in a vain attempt to mollify fans of the original, but beyond that we're back to oh dear, oh dear, oh dear, particularly if (though this might be a little unrealistic) you expect some world consistency between the original and this sequel abomination. And while we're on the subject of consistency is it asking too much to ask that the film try to even maintain its own internal consistency? (if you go to see it, and I say if advisedly, just consider, as an obvious example, the arrival, departure and some of the explicatory dialog in between related to the 'portal' and then hit 'does-not-compute'.)

The film also very definitely exemplifies the observation that you cannot make up for a poor story, and trust me it is poor, cliched and derivative, with flashy effects and action sequences. By the time it makes its mind up about what it's going to be about other than action sequences we have the shoe-horned 'what human atrocity can we nod to here' in an attempt to lend moral weight - fail. Family story - fail, at least from my point of view as I did not find the protagonist particularly likable. Love interest - fail and grrrr, no, no, no! Furthermore, the result of the inappropriately inserted action/effects/buckets-of-dice sequences detracts further because the result is lumpy, uneven, disjointed pacing with no real rhyme or reason to it other than 'oh should we stuff another action sequence in here'. 

Oh, and on the subject of effects, as a note to the effects artists, rather wasted now they've done the bloody thing, I would like to point out that since we are in a digital world here you do not need reaction based propulsion. If you had thought about this a bit you might have realised this - therefore your redesigned 'recognisers' (you know to what I refer if you are a true Tron geek) do not need jets in their feet, they may float like U.F.O.s quite happily. I may, however, concede you one point, I quite liked your geometric fireworks, but some of my friends might argue I'm prejudiced on that front. However, I am not sure that I am prepared to pay for the DVD so that I can freeze frame and identify the stellations used in the quickly fading parts of the shell explosions, I think the majority were stelations of the icosahedron, after all there are plenty of those to choose from, but there might have been at least one that was the second of the dodecahedron, but they passed rather too quickly to identify precisely. 

My initial complaint on seeing the trailers, that for a 'Tron' film the props were too real world still stands, it ought to look rather more otherworldly and alien, but that may just be prejudice carried over from the limitations of the first film's, at the time, groundbreaking C.G. However, I think the complaint stands in that it didn't really seem to be trying to look 'other'.

So if you see me in the next few weeks over the festive season, please do not mention this film, it will only start me ranting, alternatively if you do go and see it and want to join in the rant fest please feel free.

I suspect the next film that I will probably be going to see with the overtly critical eye of the loved-the-original, assuming it's not a hoax, is the Reboot film, though, if it is real, and there aren't enough C.G./I.T. jokes in the scenery I will be complaining again, bitterly.

Well I sort of dropped off the face of the world again, there'd be a reason for that. Yes I know this is long, but I'm leaving it uncut because I think some of this has been absolutely fascinating and deserves to be shared, yes, I know that's a vanity.

Towards the end of February my specialist decided that it was safe for me to start taking the medication upon which I will be dependent for the rest of my life. After picking up my first month's supply and having a moping evening out at the cinema wondering whether I was worth the cost of the medication I started taking the tablets. 

Now I knew that there was a possibility of side effects whilst starting, they pack you off with anti-emetics and anti-diarrhea medication at the same time as you pick up the medication so I was pleasantly surprised that I seemed to be having no noticeable adverse reaction to the drugs. After about six days I got a call from my father asking if I could go up and visit to help with my mother's current disposition so I headed up north and was joking with them that evening that I was going to have to complain bitterly to my specialist about the lack of side effects. Funnily enough, I had a sleepless night that night, didn't actually sleep at all, just tossed and turned in bed all night, so felt slightly tired the following day, not drowsy mind, no inkling of the possibility of sleep perfectly wide awake, so 24hrs awake and I go to bed expecting to go to sleep having not slept.

Nope, not a jot of it, another night wide awake, now I've done university/been a programmer, I know the essay/code crisis, working all night, I know what it's like after a couple of nights with no sleep, after 36hrs awake you should be getting those little jerks as you drop into microsleep as tiredness catches up with you, where were these, they were'nt occurring, I was tired, awake for 36hrs and stark staring awake, surely I'd sleep that night. Errm, actually no, another night of no sleep whatsoever and my appetite is up the spout too, it was a chore to eat even a small amount of meals.

To cut a long story marginally shorter, six, yes that's right six days after the start of this I still haven't slept for a single hours and I'm still wide awake, tired and feeling as weird as hell, no appetite and I need to return to Oxford for my two week post starting medication consultation with my specialist. Perhaps understandably my parents refused to let me drive and my father drove me down. That night we'd brought lasagne which could be microwaved for ease after our journey, now I enjoy lasagne, but my appetite and taste was so thrown that I managed a single bite and spat it out as to me it tasted disgusting, I was sort of subsisting on fruit juice and what little dinners I can force down at this point. Day seven (sleep what's sleep) and I see my sepecialist and list my problems, mention I think I've lost a little weight, I had, over a stone to be precise, was reassured by the fact that some of the things like my changed taste were well known temporary side-effects of one of the drugs that would pass presently and was referred to the pharmacist for suggestions about the more serious sleep problem, people who don't sleep tend to go mad you see, she had two things for me to try to allow me to sleep and I'd be back in two weeks if it didn't work out when we could consider changing the drug combination. My father drove me back home to my parents and that night I tried the first of the suggestions, no joy, if you've been keeping track you'll note that we are now at a grand total of 8 days without a wink or inkling of sleep, though the fish and chips for the meal that night did actually taste a bit like you'd expect fish and chips to taste. So the next night I tried the second suggestion, to miss one dose of the suspect drug taking it instead 12hrs late (the drug is one of the few in it's class to cross the blood-brain barrier, I'd been specifically interested in that one when choosing from my options for it's reputation to give interesting dreams, alas unbeknownst to me insomnia is another one of its possible listed side effects). Success, finally after 8 days without any sleep whatsoever I finally managed to sleep that night. Things have improved steadily since then, the quality of sleep has improved and for some reason the depression and low that I seem to have been suffering previously was gone, completely and utterly as if turned off at a switch, I'm actually able to concentrate on work at the moment and am having a reasonable degree of success as a freelance IT consultant. Right now some seven weeks after starting I'm not really having any side effects to the medication at all, just like the literature says, 4-6 weeks of hell after you start and then it all settles down.

Now before you all start hugsing and poor you-ing about this, a) it's done and passed, I'm fine now, just fingers crossed the drugs are doing what they're supposed to, b) the state of mind you get into after 6-8 days of complete sleep deprivation is interesting to say the least, that probably coupled with a drug that I suspect can blur the line between dreaming, lucid dreaming and in my case it would seem waking consciousness means you're not bored whilst lying in bed in the dark not being able to sleep. Just take your pick: do you want to surf through the mind space of your memories, pick and watch and freeze frame what you like; probe and expose action and consequence in exquisite detail; probe the secrets of the universe and end up having what can only be described as a (semi-)spiritual experience; have such perfect control of your mind's eye, ear that you can produce film quality visuals, fully orientable sculpture and compose full orchestral music just by thinking about it. Maybe that last was a brief but fascinating insight into the way the minds of the great visionaries and composers produce their masterpieces, perhaps just a brief glimpse of the source of genius. Well to me it seemed to explain to my satisfaction how someone such as Beethoven could still produce masterpieces despite his later deafness, there is no need for hearing when a flute sounds as a flute in the ensemble to your mind's internal ear.

It was in many respects a fascinating experience if unpleasant during the day, you feel so very weird, spaced out, not yourself, detached, you watch yourself doing things though you are doing those things of your volition. It's given me an insight into why sleep deprivation is an effective method of torture and coercion, because as fascinating as my experiences were I desperately wanted it to stop, it wasn't a pleasant experience. At the point I was leaving messages to the GM's on Patchwork Universe to make them aware of my plight it was only partly the courtesy and partly to have contact and get replies from people outside my immediate surroundings because at that point I wasn't entirely sure whether I was alive or dead and in some kind of afterlife and for some reason external replies from friends I know seemed a more reassuring thing to prove I was alive, yes, I know that's technically flawed logic, I could still be dead and in an afterlife that's clever enough to send the right sort of reply. So in summary weird, unpleasant, but I don't think I'd have missed it for anything, I almost wish I could do it again, I must be mad! And from a vanity point of view even the weight loss hasn't been all bad, my muscle definition was showing much more with less to hide it, I almost had a proper six-pack, shame I'm putting the weight back on again, hmm, must get to the gym.

In other news, finally looks like I've managed to sell the millstone hanging round my neck which is also a relief.

Well not much has been happening in <lj user="two_nukes"> world for a bit, for which I actually only have myself to blame, though I did spend a bit of last Friday night lying out watching the Perseids.

Still not got over the last job so I'm 'happy' to let my money piddle out through the mortgage for the moment, should really be trying to get a house sale moving but everything is really too much effort.

Hmm, how true is that 'not got over' bit, it's increasingly sounding like a glib excuse for not wanting to work, for being too lazy to try, am I really just throwing a tantrum because the world won't conveniently drop into my lap. I know I'm letting things slide, not been to the gym in weeks, not seeing friends, probably not really looking after myself properly but I don't seem to be able to do anything about it. I can objectively look at the behavior and see that I'm being silly though my choice of self description in my mind is normally a trifle more colourful. 

I'm still plagued by his bloody question too, I'm not sure I have the complete answer to it but I think part of it is that I desperately need a purpose, a justification, a reason, especially now, and I'm really not sure the potentiality of what you might achieve counts unless you actually have something worthwhile that you're trying to achieve in the first place. What is there to set against my cost, my choices.

Oh <lj user="two_nukes"> I see what you're doing, walls and distance, put up the signs, don't touch, don't speak, keep away. Retreating and comforting yourself with unreal fantasies. So easy to turn you back and walk away, so tempting, just like last time, yet this time there's a little sting in that tail. You built yourself that prison, denied yourself those dreams of walking out into another more exciting world if the opportunity arose. You fulfilled your own vision of idiocy, you f*@kwit, why? gave yourself a choice that should never have to be made.

I saw a meme go past in another journal where the last question was whether you'd rather have a million 'bucks' or go back in time and fix your mistakes. The respondent very sensibly followed the line that whilst there are things that might have been done differently, who was to say what actually defined a mistake. It's true we're a product of our pasts, the moving hand an' all. It's a djinn's wish to fix all your mistakes, there'd be nothing to stop you repeating them, shame, I have a list of one or two that could do with patching.

Well that's it you lucky, lucky people, I'm back in the UK after two weeks of storm chasing across Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas and briefly Colorado, just so <lj user="lanfykins"> doesn't get too envious I didn't manage to see any tornados, funnel clouds on a couple of occasions but no official tornado touchdowns, though I did get to see some very recently caused tornado damage. However, that's not to say that the break didn't have its moments, being grilled by US immigration for a hour or so upon arrival, the actually chasing when storms were available to chase, some of the most spectacular lightning shows I have ever had the pleasure to witness.

Oh yes, on the subject of US immigration, they're going to kill me if they find out, concerned as they seemed to be by my honesty about the fact that I was recently unemployed and therefore must be coming over to steal jobs from deserving Americans, I seem to have returned with a job offer. Assuming that the group I booked my holiday with get some funding and sponsorship I have an offer to join them writing data acquisition software for the sensors they'll be carrying next year and also helping with the design and build of the sensor packages. So, thinking about it, if that were to work out and I survive the potential minefield that will be trying to get myself a working visa for the States then it could be that next year I'll actually be being paid to chase tornados for the entire season. Coo, getting paid for two months of tornado chasing, let's just watch <lj user="lanfykins"> turn green with envy for a bit shall we! 

Of course this could all be a bust if the funding/visa doesn't turn up but hey, ho, it's an avenue that's opened to me into something that's both worthwhile and interesting, fulfilling two major criteria for a job I'd feel like I might be able to hack. So even if I am just clutching at straws at the moment they're very nice straws, stuck in tornado ravaged telegraph poles.

I think I'll blame that turn of events on the fact that I was wearing some of the stuff from my shopping last week. Okay so I admit my vanity was appealed to and clubbing plans were slightly modified to take into account this unexpected interest.

Now I'm sure you think you know where this narrative is going by now, and are probably hoping I stop before we get to TMI, how wrong you are. As the evening drew on my surprise interest became increasingly drunk and increasingly obnoxious so in the end he got packed off onto a bus home. This did have the disadvantage of leaving me marooned in central London at half past one in the morning, inconveniently late enough that getting home is impossible and imposing on friends or getting to the club that they'd be at becomes a tricky proposition. This left me, I thought, in the same situation as last summer, decamping to a cafe till morning trains, and indeed I did scrape up the last change in my wallet which was sufficient for a small coffee that I nursed for a considerable period of time.

There is, however, one further possibility open to a frustrated person stranded in London. I had been discounting it as a possibility as I didn't have a written note of where I needed to get to. However, what I hadn't counted on was the reliability of my memory from having looked the place up in the A-to-Z previously, I surprised myself. Therefore, a new plan was hatched. The first stage of the plan involved getting cash to replenish my funds. This was easier said than done, there seemed to be a problem with my bank's computer systems at the time as I got quite a lot of 'service currently unavailable' messages and I think I even killed a couple of cash machines attempting to perform transactions using them, at least they closed down to faults immediately after returning my card. In the end I had to resort to using my credit card to get cash, grrr, cash advance charges! However, this did allow me to progress to stage two of the plan walking and finding the place, not problems with this one. I recall noting to myself, as I crossed, how quiet the middle of the Thames was compared to the traffic noise and police sirens you get in the city. I finally got myself to where I recalled I needed to get to and looked for the place, initially no joy but taking stock, I was absolutely convinced I was in the right place, I spotted the entrance. After being assured that it wasn't possible to get a new timeclock for the old boiler, the existing timeclock having died, now behaving more like a stasisclock, I had the central heating boiler replaced. Now the only thing wrong was the timeclock, the boiler was fine, so replacing both seemed rather like overkill, after all I only wanted to tick the box that says the central heating works properly in good concience for my house sale. However, if you can't get a new timeclock compatible with an ancient boiler it's about the only option left available. So why's this important, well, as it happens the nanny state changed the rules recently so that plumbers can't do the electrical work to fit a timeclock, that has to be done by an electrician instead these days. Therefore, the new boiler is currently connected to the old timeclock, working perfectly of course. This tells me one important thing about the whole sorry mess, follow my reasoning if you will. If an old timeclock can run a new boiler and a new timeclock can run a new boiler it would suggest that a new timeclock, might, just might have been perfectly capable of running the old boiler since all the bloody thing has to do is periodically supply mains power to the ruddy boiler. Grrr, the moral of this tale, never trust tradesmen who assure you of something even when they are putatively from a trustworthy source.

Last night saw the first entry to the tally of fate points used. I was traveling home after a fine evening of sharing photographs and holiday tales with <lj user="leathellin"> and <lj user="metame">. It was after midnight and I was traveling home via the back roads (heading out from Cowley towards Stadhampton along the B480). For those of you who aren't familiar with this area south of Oxford it's open farmland with dividing hedges and barring a few twists and turns a fairly straight fast road. So there I was traveling along at 50mph, lights on full beam and suddenly it appears at the edge of the pool of light cast by my headlights, a long sizable sausage shape in the right hand lane and it's moving, ambling across the road into the left hand lane. Split second thoughts flooded through my mind: if it continues ambling across the road at its present speed we're going to intersect unless I swerve to the left or do I swerve to the right and go round the back of it, a snippet of an article in a bike magazine <cite>anything larger than a terrier will have you off</cite>, what if I swerve and it speeds up, what if I go round the back and it turns round, it's decidedly larger than a terrier, this might hurt. My bike bears down on it, headlights blazing, and just before I commit to dramatic evasive maneuvers it does something I wasn't expecting, it freezes in the glare of the headlights and stops moving any further across the road. My bike flashes past it revealing the black and white stripy muzzle of a badger and the large, very solid looking grey body; my heart's pounding and I'm fervently hoping the badger doesn't shake off its temporary paralysis and do a suicide lunge under the tyres. It doesn't and presently my heart rate is returning to normal. The rest of the journey home was satisfyingly uneventful.

My mobile phone has a design flaw, I wouldn't worry about in under most circumstances but when it manages to send the last text message you've written some 15+ times to one of your friends without your express intention you begin to feel that some action should be taken. In common with most mobiles on the market you can lock the keypad so that unexpected things don't start to happen whilst it's in your pocket. However, my phone seems to have this uncanny ability to re-enable itself when stashed in the jacket pocket of my biking leathers. I blame the unlocking mechanism, one key press followed by another key pressed within a short timeout period. You might think that sufficiently secure but my biking jacket begs to differ and seems to have the button mashing technique down pat. On at least two previous occasions I've retrieved the phone from my pocket to find it merrily in the process of adding names to my address book. This time, arriving at the gym on Tuesday, it had got more ambitious and had already managed to add ***** and +*** to the address book. I must admit I thought 'oh aye', deleted the entries, checked it hadn't placed any calls and thought no more about it, no more, that is, until I was doing a bit of housekeeping last night with the intention of clearing out the sent items folder. Imagine my surprise when I found rather more messages in there than I had expected. I don't remember sending all those I thought to myself. It soon became fairly obvious what had happened. It turns out that if you happen to press just the select button on my phone ten times from the starting screen it will send any text message present in the buffer i.e. the last one composed to the first name in the address book, a scant six more presses from that point will send the damn thing again. Repeat ad nauseam, or at least till the phone got bored of using up my monthly text entitlement in the space of about ten or fifteen minutes, turned off the predictive text dictionary, and started adding names to the address book instead. Actually I'm quite impressed, + and * aren't the easiest characters to enter into the address book by button mashing. Anyway I sent the poor sod an apology for the text bomb, though blitz might be a more accurate description, and have revised my procedures and requirements accordingly.
  • After sending a message always clear the text buffer, there are some things you just don't want propagating randomly.
  • Any mobile phone should not be unlockable by exposed buttons, ever, no really.
He he, I can just tell how popular I'm going to be in the phone shop when I go looking for a replacement.

My parents are here this weekend helping me start the mammoth task of sorting and boxing in preparation for my intended house downsizing in the new year. They arrived before I was home from work and had started doing stuff. As it happened my father got chatting to the father of my next door neighbour's wife who was visiting to help look after their children whilst she's ill. Things were going fine, they were having a very sociable chat up until the point that my father was brought to the point of incoherent rage by something that was said. Of course I didn't discover this state of affairs until after dinner when my father said to me 'I'm going to tell you something that's going to make you angry.' He then proceeded to explain to me what he had discovered in the course of that conversation earlier in the day. You may recall that a little while ago I mentioned that I was having my house redecorated. This meant that I endured a week or so of complete turmoil with workmen staying in the house, lack of facilities for making dinner, etc, etc. During this time I had to leave the workmen to their own devices while I went out to work, trust me with as much turmoil as there was you wanted to be out of the house as much as possible, most people who have comparable work done usually stay in a hotel for the duration. Shortly after the work was finished I was accosted one morning by my arch-nemesis (neighbour the other way) who accused me of being discourteous for not informing him that I was having my house decorated. Quite frankly since it didn't involve his property in the slightest (we're detached that way, houses that is) I hadn't even remotely considered it any of his business. Anyway, after letting him insult me some more and almost failing to resist soking him on the nose I had let this pass. In the light of this, my reaction to my father's news, namely hitting the roof in fury, is probably understandable. It turns out that, whilst I had been out at work one day, arch-nemesis had approached one of the workmen and asked, get this, actually asked whether he could look round. Unfortunately the workman had rather foolishly said yes. Arch-nemesis then proceeded to wander at will through my entire house, every single room, before leaving and pronouncing the place 'a nasty dirty house' to all and sundry around. After I had managed to calm down from spluttering swear words, it came down to deciding what to do. It's probably just as well that arch-nemesis is on holiday at the moment or I'd be up on assault charges. As it was trespass was considered as an actual formal charge or at least talking to a solicitor about whether that was viable and as a minimum getting a solicitor's letter written. The guy's retired and is therefore old enough to know that the workman wouldn't have the authority to grant him free access to the house, but unfortunately it's hard to pin that sort of thing down to make trespass stick and I don't really want to start that sort of a wrangle now when I'm planning to be selling in the new year since these days they ask questions on the property questionnaire about relations with neighbours. After some heated discussion of the right course of action my anger had subsided enough to allow me to look at the situation and the source of my anger with a little more perspective and rationality. I realised that my actual target for anger was the workman. Granted that arch-nemesis' request was inappropriate but you cant take him to task for asking, though making snide comments behind your back is another matter. However, you can find fault with the answer 'yes' being given to that question, firstly because it's a serious betrayal of client trust and secondly from the point of view of the contractor, should an unauthorised person get injured on the site there are liability and insurance issues to deal with. The overall decision is that I am making a formal complaint to the contractor requesting that the offending party be disciplined for the reasons above. However, that isn't to say that arch-nemesis is going to be getting away with it, it was completely inappropriate for him to put the workman in that position in the first place and he should at least apologise to them for doing so, particularly as it's going to cause them to be disciplined. Not to mention how much of a hypocrite he's turned out to have been accusing me of discourtesy when he's been wandering through my property completely uninvited, it's at the very least impolite to rude and verging on the criminal. By the time I'm finished with him I'm intending to make him feel about an inch high, he's still on holiday so I've got plenty of time to come up with some choice lines and at least this way tenuously there is no dispute between neighbours, just a matter of courtesies given and recieved. I shall just gloss over the fact that my father also discovered from the same source the reason that arch-nemesis had a low wall built between our properties. Apparently quote unquote it was to 'spite my neighbour'. Charming I must say. However, privately, I do obtain a good deal of amusement from The Dandelion Wall, my name for it, you see, arch-nemesis' official reason for having it built was to prevent dandelions seeding themselves from my lawn into his. Of course, as everyone knows, wind bourne dandelion seeds are well known for their inability to cross three foot high walls!

Well it's been getting slightly frustrating, despite my best efforts of rolling on the power I have been unable to get my silver steed to paw the air, so in desparation I resorted to the intergnat last night for some pointers. There were a number of recommendations (well three commonly agreed upon) depending upon the friskiness of one's steed. The simplest method applies to the friskiest of steeds and then they generally increase in complexity as one's steed becomes more sedate. Of course the key information was the hints about how to apply the power. Now it so happened that this morning I had a reasonable stretch of clear road available to me, I was in a good mood for reasons expanded upon below and consequently feeling daring, I'd just turned onto the road from a roundabout, wasn't going very fast, and was in first gear so the stage was set. What the hell, I thought, I'd give the simple method a go. The first and simplest method for frisky steeds is to ride the beast in first gear until about one third of maximum rpm and then wind on full throttle in the space of about a second. I think my problems previously have been not to wind on the throttle fast enough and bottle out too soon due to the remarkable acceleration that you develop at higher revs in first. Not this morning. 1st gear, 5000 rpm, 20mph and we're ready to go. I realise I have to adjust my grip on the throttle so that I can give it the full handful and then we're off... he he, what they really don't impress on you is quite the degree of acceleration this operation provides, there are some really noticeable forces going on. The tachometer needle swishes round the dial, 8, 9, 10,000rpm still no pawing at the air, I'm beginning to fear that my steed isn't going to be frisky enough to rear using this method and I contemplate easing off as the acceleration is quite... dramatic shall we say. Of course in the time it takes to consider this course of action the throttle is still cranked wide open and the beast is still picking up speed and then it happened. I'm not sure exactly where between 10,000 and 14,000rpm it happened but suddenly I feel and see it, we have liftoff, the nose of the beast rises and does a slight nod down and up as I modulate the throttle slightly in surprise/alarm before it settles back down on the ground as I unwind the throttle again. Not the world's longest or highest wheelie, but a first time for the and it did at least prove to me quite how deliberate (and brave) you have to be to coax a power wheelie out of the beast. However, at that point, immediately after the event, there was a certain amount of jubilation and laughter going on inside my helmet which continued for much of the rest of my journey to work. I'd got my proof positive that I was capable of pulling wheelies. Control for longer runs and wheelies in general I think will wait for better riding conditions next year. Now none of this would have happened this morning if it hadn't been for a thought I had whilst cleaning my teeth. I'd been having an issue with some of the rtl source code of the language we develop in at work. The rtl code is a bit overly eager about doing a certain thing before I'm fully ready for it. Unfortunately I can't move any of my later stuff earlier because it has its own dependencies on other rtl gubbins that is done at the same time as my problem chunk of rtl code. The solution would have been very simple if the rtl writers had thought of this eventuality but they hadn't so I was left with a problem, until the thought of this morning. I remembered that the bit of the rtl I have a problem with being done early is accomplished by using a pointer to the method to be executed and I had access to that pointer. So suppose that pointer got played with a bit before the rtl started using it. Suppose that pointer was pointed at something innocuous that didn't give me problems, like a function doing nothing for example. Then afterwards after all my later stuff gets finished I invoke the method that should have been executed by the over eager rtl code, everything is hunky dory with the world, yes? Right! This was a good thought, triumphs over the rtl, I left the house on top of the world, got into work in an even better mood, tried out my proposed solution and then sat and was smug for a bit because it worked exactly as planned, problem solved!
